title: Student Test Scores Analysis
description: Analysis of First Year BSIT students' midterm scores using Frequency Distribution Table.

questions.question: How many students scored between 70 and 79?
questions.explanation: Looking at the frequency (f) column for class interval 70-79, we can see f = 15 students.

questions.question: What is the median class in this distribution?
questions.explanation: Since N=50, we look for N/2=25 in the CF column. The class where CF first reaches or exceeds 25 is 70-79 (CF=28).

questions.question: Calculate the mean score (rounded to one decimal).
questions.explanation: Using the formula Mean = ΣfX / Σf = 3865 / 50 = 77.3

questions.question: Which interval represents the mode class?
questions.explanation: The mode class has the highest frequency. Looking at the f column, 70-79 has the highest frequency of 15 students.

title: Height Data Analysis
description: Analysis of student heights data and FDT construction.

questions.question: Using Sturges' rule (K ≈ 1 + 3.322 log n), what is the suggested number of classes?
Given range=21 (175-154) and using 6 classes, what should be the class size (C) rounded up?
questions.explanation: Class size C = Range/K = 21/6 = 3.5, rounded up to 4

questions.question: What is the class mark of the interval 158-161?
questions.explanation: Class mark = (Lower limit + Upper limit)/2 = (158 + 161)/2 = 159.5

title: Exam Scores Analysis
description: Analysis of exam scores using Frequency Distribution Table.

questions.question: What is the mean score of the students?
Which class interval has the highest frequency?
questions.explanation: The class interval 70-79 has the highest frequency of 15.

questions.question: What is the median class?
questions.explanation: N/2 = 20. The median class is 60-69, where CF first reaches 17 and exceeds 20 in the next class.

title: Age Distribution Analysis
description: Analysis of age distribution using Frequency Distribution Table.

questions.question: What is the mean age of the employees?
Which class interval has the lowest frequency?
questions.explanation: The class interval 60-69 has the lowest frequency of 2.

questions.question: What is the modal class?
questions.explanation: The modal class is 40-49, which has the highest frequency of 12.

title: Graphical Representation: Histogram, Polygon, Ogive
description: Covers reading and interpreting graphs based on frequency distribution tables.

questions.question: Which graph uses rectangles to represent frequencies of classes?
questions.explanation: Histogram uses bars (rectangles) whose heights show frequency and widths show class intervals.

questions.question: What does a frequency polygon connect?
questions.explanation: A frequency polygon connects the midpoints (class marks) of each class using straight lines.

questions.question: The Ogive graph is used to represent what type of frequency?
questions.explanation: Ogive shows cumulative frequencies — used to find medians and percentiles.

questions.question: If the highest bar in a histogram corresponds to 20–29, what does it mean?
questions.explanation: The tallest bar indicates the class interval with the highest frequency — the mode class.

title: Measures of Central Tendency
description: Covers computation and interpretation of mean, median, and mode for FDTs.

questions.question: What measure of central tendency is found by summing all data values and dividing by the total number?
questions.explanation: The mean is the arithmetic average of all data values.

questions.question: In an ungrouped data set, the median is the value that:
options: Divides the data into two equal parts
Is the average of all data
Is the difference between the highest and lowest
questions.explanation: The median divides ordered data into two equal halves.

questions.question: Which formula is used to find the class mark?
questions.explanation: The class mark is the midpoint — found by averaging the lower and upper limits.

questions.question: What is the mode in an FDT?
questions.explanation: Mode is the class with the highest frequency — the most common value range.

title: UNIT 1: Introduction to Statistics and Data
description: Covers the definition, importance, and methods of data collection in Statistics.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of statistics?
options: To collect, analyze, and interpret data
questions.explanation: Statistics is primarily used to collect, analyze, and interpret data.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of quantitative data?
questions.explanation: Heights of students are numerical and measurable, making them quantitative data.

questions.question: What is the difference between discrete and continuous data?
options: Discrete data is countable, continuous data is measurable
Discrete data is measurable, continuous data is countable
Discrete data is qualitative, continuous data is quantitative
Discrete data is categorical, continuous data is numerical
questions.explanation: Discrete data is countable (e.g., number of students), while continuous data is measurable (e.g., height, weight).

questions.question: Which method of data collection involves observing and recording behavior?
questions.explanation: The Observation Method involves watching and recording behavior.

questions.question: What is the main advantage of using a questionnaire for data collection?
options: It allows for large-scale data collection
It is only useful for qualitative data
questions.explanation: Questionnaires allow for large-scale data collection efficiently.

title: UNIT 2: Data Presentation
description: Discusses tabular and graphical presentation of data including Frequency Distribution Table (FDT).

questions.question: Which type of graph is best for comparing proportions of a whole?
questions.explanation: Pie charts are ideal for comparing proportions of a whole.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of a histogram?
options: To display the frequency of continuous data
questions.explanation: Histograms display the frequency of continuous data.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a component of a Frequency Distribution Table (FDT)?
questions.explanation: Standard Deviation is not a component of an FDT.

questions.question: What is the purpose of cumulative frequency in an FDT?
options: To find the median and quartiles
questions.explanation: Cumulative frequency helps in finding the median and quartiles.

title: UNIT 3: Constructing a Frequency Distribution Table
description: Learn the step-by-step process of constructing an FDT and its components.

questions.question: What is the first step in constructing an FDT?
options: Find the range of the data
Arrange the data in ascending order
questions.explanation: The first step is to arrange the data in ascending order.

questions.question: What is the formula to calculate the range of data?
options: Range = Number of classes / Class size
Range = Total frequency / Number of classes
questions.explanation: Range is calculated as the difference between the highest and lowest values.

questions.question: What is the purpose of class boundaries in an FDT?
options: To ensure no gaps or overlaps between classes
questions.explanation: Class boundaries ensure there are no gaps or overlaps between classes.

questions.question: What is the class size if the range is 40 and the number of classes is 5?
questions.explanation: Class size = Range / Number of classes = 40 / 5 = 8.

title: UNIT 4: Measures of Central Tendency (Ungrouped Data)
description: Covers mean, median, and mode for ungrouped or raw data.

questions.question: What is the median of the data set: 5, 7, 9, 11, 13, 15?
questions.explanation: For an even number of data points, the median is the average of the two middle numbers: (9 + 11) / 2 = 10.

questions.question: What is the mode of the data set: 2, 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 6, 6, 7?
questions.explanation: The mode is the most frequently occurring value, which is 6.

questions.question: What is the mean of the data set: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50?

title: UNIT 5: Measures of Central Tendency (Grouped Data)
description: Learn how to compute the mean, median, and mode using grouped data formulas.

questions.question: What is the formula for the mean in grouped data?
questions.explanation: The mean in grouped data is calculated using ΣfX / Σf.

questions.question: What is the median class if the total frequency (N) is 50 and the cumulative frequency (CF) reaches 25 in the class 30-39?
questions.explanation: The median class is where the cumulative frequency first reaches or exceeds N/2 (25).

questions.question: What is the mode class if the highest frequency is in the class 40-49?
questions.explanation: The mode class is the class with the highest frequency, which is 40-49.

title: UNIT 6: Measures of Position
description: Explains quartiles, deciles, and percentiles and how to interpret them.

questions.question: What is the formula for the first quartile (Q1)?
questions.explanation: The formula for the first quartile is Q1 = L + ((N/4 - CF<) / f) * i.

questions.question: What does the third quartile (Q3) represent?
questions.explanation: The third quartile (Q3) represents the highest 25% of the data.

questions.question: What is the relationship between quartiles and percentiles?
questions.explanation: The first quartile (Q1) is the 25th percentile (P25), the second quartile (Q2) is the 50th percentile (P50), and the third quartile (Q3) is the 75th percentile (P75).

title: UNIT 7: Interpretation and Common Mistakes
description: Identifies common errors and key reminders in data analysis.

questions.question: What is a common mistake when calculating the median in grouped data?
questions.explanation: Forgetting to use cumulative frequency is a common mistake when calculating the median in grouped data.

questions.question: What does CF< represent in an FDT?
options: Cumulative frequency including the current class
Cumulative frequency before the current class
questions.explanation: CF< represents the cumulative frequency before the current class.

questions.question: Why is it important to round the class size correctly?
options: To ensure the data is qualitative
To avoid gaps or overlaps in class intervals
questions.explanation: Rounding the class size correctly avoids gaps or overlaps in class intervals.

questions.question: Ako Parin ba? or Siya na talaga??
questions.explanation: Mag aral muna ahh puro landi eh
